founders.name: Jacob Thornton, Founder
founders.description:
Jacob Thornton has been doing software development in the bay area for over a decade, as an early employee at startups like Twitter, Medium, and Coinbase.

During this time he contributed to several large open source projects (most notably as the co-creator of Twitter Bootstrap), given talks around the world (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UIDb6VBO9os), and written several chapters in technical books (beautiful javascript, if Hemingway wrote javascript).

founders.name: Ian Ownbey, Founder
founders.description: I have worked for a number of consumer tech companies ranging from Twitter in 2010 to Coinbase in 2018. I started as a backend engineer using Ruby on Rails and then eventually moved up the stack to iOS engineering, React Native engineering and now mostly React. I enjoy hanging out with my cat when not working.

**Company Overview: Pierre**

Founded in 2023 and part of Y Combinator’s W23 batch, Pierre is based in New York and is redefining the way coding teams handle collaboration. With a tight-knit team of just two, Pierre’s mission is straightforward: to build a better GitHub that facilitates more enjoyable and efficient code reviews.

**What is Pierre?**

At its core, Pierre innovates the traditional code review process by eliminating the need for pull requests. Instead, every change—regardless of its merge status—is automatically reviewable. This means developers can comment, approve, or react to changes in real-time, effectively streamlining the workflow. Authors control when to merge their changes, while reviewers have the flexibility to review them on their own time.

**How Does AI Fit In?**

Pierre doesn’t just stop at simplifying code reviews. It’s built with an AI-first approach that enhances the user experience by:

- Summarizing diffs
- Highlighting significant changes
- Categorizing work types
- Suggesting fixes for failed CI tests

This automation is designed to occur all the time, as soon as code is pushed, placing AI at the center of its functionality.

**Features and Innovations**

1. **No More Pull Requests**: Every change is made reviewable instantly, facilitating smoother interactions and quicker approvals.
   
2. **AI-Powered Assistance**: From summarizing code to offering suggestions, AI helps developers spend less time managing reviews and more time coding.

3. **User-Centric Design**: Pierre learns about user preferences, tailoring the interface and notifications to focus on what truly matters to each team.

4. **Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment (CI/CD)**: Pierre has integrated new pipelines to enhance deployment processes efficiently.

5. **Accessibility**: Enhancements in UI components ensure that usability is prioritized, reflecting a modern approach to software development.

**Community Engagement**

Pierre fosters a vibrant community on platforms like Discord and Twitter, encouraging users to join the conversation and share their experiences.

**Pricing and Availability**

While specific pricing details are not widely available yet, potential users are encouraged to join the waitlist on their website [heypierre.app](https://heypierre.app) to stay updated on developments and access early features.

**Conclusion**

Pierre is not just about creating a new platform; it aims to fundamentally change the way developers engage with their work. By prioritizing ease of use, collaborative features, and AI enhancements, Pierre stands as a promising player in the developer tools arena. If you're a part of a coding team looking for a more joyful and efficient way to handle reviews, Pierre could be worth keeping an eye on.
